allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Nice phone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2024
allReviews.body: Bought this Pixel 9 256GB new, direct from Amazon during the early Black Friday sale. The discount was even better than Google's. Phone arrived undamaged and in working, new condition. Have had the phone for a couple of weeks. No issues so far. Upgraded from a 7 year old Moto G 5. My review is skewed by my experience that is limited to budget phones.The squared edges does get some getting used to. Screen looks good, glass doesn't smear too quickly. Audio, connection, web browsing speed are satisfactory. Camera is good. Wish there was a 3.5mm audio jack and a microSD card slot like my previous phones. Phone surface is slippery to hold without a rubbery case. Haven't had a chance to try all the AI features. Haven't experienced overheating or slow charging that other people have mentioned. But I do not play mobile games, and I use an Anker 25W charger.As a preferer of smaller phones, the 6" height of this Pixel 9 is the maximum I'd like. It is also heaver than I'm used to. I couldn't find any budget phones I liked that were 6" or smaller, and the price is out of my normal target range. But the big Black Friday discount, and the 7 years of promised software support from Google, were some of the reasons for my purchase.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Perfect android phone with best camera
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2024
allReviews.body: The Pixel 9 is the best phone for anyone looking for a compact device, as most phones these days feel too large in hand. The camera is excellent for everyday photography, with Google's software making casual shots effortless and consistently impressive.Battery life easily lasts a full day, providing around 5-6 hours of screen time, primarily for checking emails, social media, and taking a few photos.I got it during a sale, which made it a great value for money. The design looks premium and stands out from other Android devices. The haptic feedback is top-notch, enhancing the overall user experience.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The perfect phone for most people
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2025
allReviews.body: I had a Pixel 6 for several years until it died.  The Pixel 9 does everything I liked about the 6 and fixes the few annoyances I experienced with the 6...mainly the issue of failed fingerprint recognition.  On Pixel 9, face recognition and fingerprint recognition make for a seamless experience...the phone unlocks when I pick it up.Otherwise bright clear screen, fast response times and long battery life plus wireless charging have made this the perfect phone for me.  It also is much better than the 6 in maintaining Bluetooth connections.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I'm mainly glad
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2024
allReviews.body: Reviewing after switching from pixel 6a.I like 9's front design more. I thought the round camera deisgn would look vulgar and too much, but appears it's so only in the pictures and it looks even better than older pixels'. However, I didn't like the back glass, it's slippery, I'm afraid to touch the phone without a case.Battery life is good, the same as pixel 6a's to me. Functionality is perfect so far. Phone unlockability could be improved, it doesn't recognise my finger sometimes and my face during certain lights, but it's not a major issue to me.The camera quality is no doubt excellent, however the back camera's colors could be more "alive" and have better contrast.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Camera blows my mind and water proofing already save the day
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2024
allReviews.body: I don't know if the picture will come across on here but I live in Houston the brightest city in Texas at night. I can see stars I usually only see out at big bend. The second week I owned the phone it fell from the top of my dash into a 40oz ocean water from sonic it was completely submerged didn't even drop the call. Gemini is great I find myself using it everyday. Phone is super responsive and fast at every task. I want to play with desktop mode and do a review on that as well. I have a magsafe m.2 SSD holder with USB c connection so I have an extra 2 TB to play with. I work in very harsh environments lots of dust that ruins glasses in no time but this phone is holding up with just a few scratches even after dropping it from 15ft onto gravel screen first! I am really hard on phones my pixel 6a and 4a were great and after a short foray back into Motorola I came back to the 9 and will never look back. It's like these are the smartest phones everything else feels like an old Nokia. Seriously I don't know why anyone wasted their time on apple or Samsung y'all are living in 2006 I'm in 2060.

allReviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Amazing phone, slippery as hell
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2025
allReviews.body: You can check out youtube for the pixel 9 if you want an in depth review. The ones I watched were pretty accurate. Great phone, great camera. Works amazing. The one thing they don't metion is that holding this phone without a case is like trying to hold onto a very thin wet bar of soap. It slips right out of your hand, vibrates right off the table, and glides right out of every pocket. Get a case when you order the phone. You won't regret it.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    a powerful pixel 9 phone loaded with Google apps
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2025
allReviews.body: I bought the Pixel 9. It's a small, powerful phone with a weird bulging Camra/Flashlight area. It only comes with a USB C cable and a pin to remove/add your physical sim card.  It does not come with a charger so be prepared to spend an additional amount on Google's 45w wall adaptor.  I love that Google used minimal paper packaging. I highly recommend buying a case and screen protector to protect this investment.At the time of this writing this review, I have only played with my phone for about a week runtime.  I was disappointed this phone cannot take smooth photos of the night sky stars or even the moon (an enlarged white light source)!  However, for all other daytime casual photo taking abilities, this phone impressed me with the speed in which it takes clear, vibrant photos.  Taking screenshots of web pages is amazing since it gives me the option to take a long vertical screenshot. The fingerprint unlocking feature isn't reliable, so I don't recommend using it.  I am slightly disappointed the AI translation feature only works with videos played on the phone and the words fade out too quickly after it was spoken.  Browsing web pages on this phone is superbly faster than my 4-year-old Samsung phone. I am still learning about this phone, or more precisely google apps LOL, but I'm loving it so far.  Google Lens' ability to identify items I photograph is 95% accurate. I would recommend this phone to anyone who lives, eats, breathes and enjoys using Google apps.

For some reason the camera section sticks out farther than the back of the phone which seems odd, however the cases adapt for the extension.  It takes very nice pictures and has several cool editing features.

    Good looking phone with good camera and satellite connectivity.
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2024
allReviews.body: I don't need a super duper phone. I just needed a phone with emergency satellite connectivity to replace my SPOT4 satellite messenger and take a good video, so that I can replace a couple of electronics on my trips. This phone checks both boxes. It's a handsome phone to boot. Oh, and the speaker sounds terrific too. I'm so used cheap Chinese phone with tinny sound that this phone was a treat. All at half the price of iPhone.I could've had it practically for free if I waited a few days. Mint Mobile cut their price on black Pixel 9 to $249 when packaged with 1 yr subscription of their unlimited plan for $180. I could return mine and get that one instead, but I like this white phone enough that I'm keeping it.

allReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Decent Phone, Fuzzy Sound in Headphones at First
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2024
allReviews.body: Overall, I think this is a pretty good phone. The camera quality in the rearview is good, especially in good lighting. The front camera is excellent; it enhances the details of your face and has a crisp, clear quality. I also like the AI features of the phone. It is nice to be able to erase things that are not needed in the background of pictures. I also like adding things to the background for fun. It is fun to mess around with, but it could be better. It won't always generate what you ask for. Additionally, the fingerprint and face recognition on the phone are excellent; the phone always opens upon recognition of my face or fingerprint. In terms of the battery life, it is just okay. It lasts all day with heavy use, but I have to charge it after that. Sometimes I have to charge it sooner than the day's end if the brightness is high. I've had phones before that last for a couple of days before I need to charge them. Another issue is that if I'm running Google Maps and Spotify at the same time, the phone starts to heat up. It has never overheated from doing this, but it is something that I've noticed. Also, my phone calls sounded fuzzy in my headphones from the beginning. I know that the headphones weren't the problem because they work fine on any other device. However, I tried resetting the Bluetooth, and that seemed to fix the issue. If there the issue doesn't come up again, then I'll bump up the score to a four. However, if I have more issues with this, then I'm going to be irritated.

allReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The Pixel 3 was better.
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2024
allReviews.body: This phone is evidence of the tech worlds deep overselling of AI. Out of the box, the gestures to swap between open apps on your phone and close them is virtually unusable. The gesture to circle something and Google search it, that's what's easy. Screen capture on a button on the side? Nope, launch the AI assistant, which is just the old assistant with a new name. Fortunately you can bring back the virtual buttons in the settings, rendering the phone almost functional.Just not for voice mail or MMS messages which I keep receiving errors on. Custom support chat can't even be bothered to read what you tell them so you have to type it three times, and their solutions just don't work. Up next on my list? Spending hours on the phone with their customer support.The phone feels great, but it's so slick, it slid from the center of a hardcover book (library book with the protective cover) off my side table with no force applied. Case is a must for grip. Even for flat surfaces apparently.This phone was a big jump for me from a Pixel 3 to a Pixel 9 and so far, nothing about the 9 is impressive outside of the fact that it made it through the day with battery to spare. When I got my 3 I was blown away. What I got a few days ago is unimpressive for six full years of development time.For the cost and the time jump. I wanted to be wowed. I was not wowed. The phone still takes good photos, you get good volume out of the speakers, although I think I liked the tone of my 3 better. Oh well, maybe in another 6-7 years Google will make a phone that functions better in its fundamentals instead of chasing unnecessary features in response to fragile tech trends.

3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good Not Great
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2025
allReviews.body: Side by side comparison between my Pixel 7 and my Pixel 9 I had to wonder where is the upgrade? Surprisingly photos in both low and high lighting are near identical. The Pixel 9 photos have a warmer tint and reduced sharpness but otherwise the camera in real world use hasn't been noticeably upgraded. The UI is the same as they both run the same version of Android and they are both equally responsive. The fingerprint reader on the 9 is noticeably improved and there are a few AI gimmicks thrown in. If your phone is 5+ years old this is probably a good choice for an upgrade, otherwise you should wait for more noticeable hardware improvements.

allReviews.body: I mean if the standard price was 550(that's how much i paid before tax), this would 100% be a 5 star product.  If i could give it 3.5 stars i would.  I only bought this cause cause my pixel 4a is showing some age and seems like a great phone for the next 5-7 years.My only thing is that you can't really rate a phone after a week, a month, or even a year.  I bought it cause it seemed like a pretty good deal at the time but early adopters of new technology often have that "what if i waited" mindset when a more polished version arrives a year later.Solid phone so far, would never pay full price for it, but if I had a crystal ball I could give a better review

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Decent Phone, Fuzzy Sound in Headphones at First
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Overall, I think this is a pretty good phone. The camera quality in the rearview is good, especially in good lighting. The front camera is excellent; it enhances the details of your face and has a crisp, clear quality. I also like the AI features of the phone. It is nice to be able to erase things that are not needed in the background of pictures. I also like adding things to the background for fun. It is fun to mess around with, but it could be better. It won't always generate what you ask for. Additionally, the fingerprint and face recognition on the phone are excellent; the phone always opens upon recognition of my face or fingerprint. In terms of the battery life, it is just okay. It lasts all day with heavy use, but I have to charge it after that. Sometimes I have to charge it sooner than the day's end if the brightness is high. I've had phones before that last for a couple of days before I need to charge them. Another issue is that if I'm running Google Maps and Spotify at the same time, the phone starts to heat up. It has never overheated from doing this, but it is something that I've noticed. Also, my phone calls sounded fuzzy in my headphones from the beginning. I know that the headphones weren't the problem because they work fine on any other device. However, I tried resetting the Bluetooth, and that seemed to fix the issue. If there the issue doesn't come up again, then I'll bump up the score to a four. However, if I have more issues with this, then I'm going to be irritated.

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    The Pixel 3 was better.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2024
criticalReviews.body: This phone is evidence of the tech worlds deep overselling of AI. Out of the box, the gestures to swap between open apps on your phone and close them is virtually unusable. The gesture to circle something and Google search it, that's what's easy. Screen capture on a button on the side? Nope, launch the AI assistant, which is just the old assistant with a new name. Fortunately you can bring back the virtual buttons in the settings, rendering the phone almost functional.Just not for voice mail or MMS messages which I keep receiving errors on. Custom support chat can't even be bothered to read what you tell them so you have to type it three times, and their solutions just don't work. Up next on my list? Spending hours on the phone with their customer support.The phone feels great, but it's so slick, it slid from the center of a hardcover book (library book with the protective cover) off my side table with no force applied. Case is a must for grip. Even for flat surfaces apparently.This phone was a big jump for me from a Pixel 3 to a Pixel 9 and so far, nothing about the 9 is impressive outside of the fact that it made it through the day with battery to spare. When I got my 3 I was blown away. What I got a few days ago is unimpressive for six full years of development time.For the cost and the time jump. I wanted to be wowed. I was not wowed. The phone still takes good photos, you get good volume out of the speakers, although I think I liked the tone of my 3 better. Oh well, maybe in another 6-7 years Google will make a phone that functions better in its fundamentals instead of chasing unnecessary features in response to fragile tech trends.

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Medium quality phone, could have been better
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2025
criticalReviews.body: After a month of use, I guess I was not very impressed with this. It works terribly during calls as the microphone turns off and you have to reset it multiple times, restart the phone or have other person call you. Camera quality is also okay, not too great for the price. I haven't experienced much heat from the phone. Screen quality is okay. Overall it gives a feel of medium low range phone.

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Good Not Great
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2025
criticalReviews.body: Side by side comparison between my Pixel 7 and my Pixel 9 I had to wonder where is the upgrade? Surprisingly photos in both low and high lighting are near identical. The Pixel 9 photos have a warmer tint and reduced sharpness but otherwise the camera in real world use hasn't been noticeably upgraded. The UI is the same as they both run the same version of Android and they are both equally responsive. The fingerprint reader on the 9 is noticeably improved and there are a few AI gimmicks thrown in. If your phone is 5+ years old this is probably a good choice for an upgrade, otherwise you should wait for more noticeable hardware improvements.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Avoid this phone if you want to call somebody and put it to your ear.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2025
criticalReviews.body: Avoid this phone like the plague.  It sucks.  The ear proximity sensor turns the phone on while it is at your ear, your cheek pushes the screen and you don't know what happens.  Almost always hangs up on everybody.  To use it, the user MUST use a bluetooth device or the speaker phone.  Worse, when you are talking to somebody, it will not allow you to use the phone, the screen senses that your thumb is your ear, and it turns off the screen (so you have to use speakerphone to look at your phone while talking.).

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Getting better - But have to factor in how Google treats employees
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I got a Pixel 9 directly from the Google store because they offered the most generous trade in policy (Samsung needs to step it up here). I had a Pixel 7 and I will tell you objectively that the 9 is a great improvement. The camera is better than the S24 IMO and it feels more premium than older models. However, the Pixel is not as fast and noticeably not as smooth as the S24 when scrolling. They boast a high refresh rate on this model, but the icons just don't flow as smoothly as a S24 when scrolling. The difference is noticeable..Samsung has this iPhone smooth scrolling experience, the Pixel 9 doesnt.Now, why the very low review if the phone is decent? One must consider the whole picture including the ethics of the manufacturer when purchasing. It was reported to me from an inside source that Google is firing (not laying off) early career employees right before the holidays. Reading in between the lines my interpretation was that they are firing (thus damaging the careers of young professionals) vs. laying off to save a few bucks. If true, this sort of potentially unethical behavior should be reflected in the consumer sentiment and reviews. In my case this was a gift, but I would have bought an S24 for this reason on my own.

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Pixel 9 Pro XL inherited severe long-lasting pixel problems
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2024
criticalReviews.body: 1. Moving your non-image/video documents from earlier pixel to a new one is still mission impossible... Copying through USB-C on Windows PC is the only option (per Google sales) but the copying is broken constantly2. Still very fast battery drainage, poor power saving control,  poor WiFi-cell switching, blocked icloud email access, blocked Baidu cloud access...After all, Google is a SW company, not really a (top) device company.Great camera though.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Its a good for nothing phone.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Its a good for nothing phone. Never ever buy it, we moved from Iphone to Pixel 9 , after 3 moths it stopped working and they are asking $690 for refurbished device. Never buy this device , you are going to loese money ,,,

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
    este telefono una ******
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2024
criticalReviews.body: por favor google arreglen el soporte de google fi

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Save your money as you will absolutely hate this piece of garbage. You have been warned
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Save your money as you will absolutely hate this piece of garbage. You have been warned. It is a heavy brick that has a never ending list of settings (you will never get to all of them) all so Google can take your data from you and use it for ads and worse. Nothing on this phone is new or unique, the AI stuff is crap, the current version of Android is decidedly worse than older version, as they aren't adding good useful features. It is ALL about taking your data and marketing to you. It is time to break Google up into a handful of smaller companies (Apple needs to be broken up too).

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Slow charging, blurry pics and bloat
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2024
criticalReviews.body: My pixel came preloaded with every single Google app. Many like Google TV will not uninstall. The wireless charging is terrible. Going from 30%, with adaptive charging disabled, using a 15watt charger takes 8 hours!! Pics in low light have a hard time focusing. Trying to get a pic of textthat isn't blurry is difficult. Definitely a downgrade from other flagship phones.

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Phone is good but heats a lot esp when charging
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Heating issues, heating issues do not go away after initial usage/updates. Gets uncomfotably hot when charging. Returning and evaluating other options.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    I wanted to like it.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2025
criticalReviews.body: The dimensions are good.The pictures could be better. The performance could be better. Compared to my s20, this phone lags a noticable amount. The screen looked like it had burn-in or splothiness that wouldnt go away (onvious grain).  Photos are meh.  The call quality is crap, it's processing of information is slow, And it's 4 years newer. I wish I never bought this phone. Keep searching.

criticalReviews.title: Según yo tiene varios bugs es sistema operativo de Google.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in Mexico on February 17, 2025
criticalReviews.body: Tiene bugs

productDetails.productTitle: Google Pixel 9 - Unlocked Android Smartphone with Gemini, 24-Hour Battery, Advanced Camera, and 6.3" Actua Display - Obsidian - 256 GB
featureBullets: Google Pixel 9 with Gemini gets the best of Google AI first, so you can take amazing photos, make edits like magic, and get things done even easier
Unlocked Android phone gives you the flexibility to change carriers and choose your own data plan[1]; it works with Google Fi, Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T, and other major carriers
The award-winning Pixel Camera includes a 50 MP main sensor for incredible image and video quality, and a new 48 MP ultrawide camera for stunning Macro Focus

Make your photos better than you can imagine with Google AI; take a picture and be in it too with Add Me[2]; Best Take helps everyone look their best; and with Magic Editor, you can reframe photos, reimagine the scenery, and more[2]

Get more info quickly with Gemini, your built-in AI assistant[3]; instead of typing, use Gemini Live; it follows along even if you change the topic or switch the question[30]; and Pixel Screenshots helps you save things you’ll want to remember later
